Name: Mahatma Gandhi
Early Life: Born on October 2, 1869, in Porbandar, Gujarat. Gandhi was raised in a religious family and later studied law in London.
Major Contributions: Leader of the Indian independence movement. Advocated for non-violence (Ahimsa) and Satyagraha (nonviolent resistance).
Role in Freedom Movement: Led nationwide movements like the Salt March, Quit India Movement, and Civil Disobedience.
Legacy: Known as the 'Father of the Nation,' Gandhi's philosophy influenced civil rights movements worldwide.
Quotes: 'Be the change that you wish to see in the world.'
Honors and Awards: Honored as the 'Father of the Nation,' posthumous honors include statues and memorials worldwide.

Name: Jawaharlal Nehru
Early Life: Born on November 14, 1889, in Allahabad. He was educated at Harrow, Eton, and later at Trinity College, Cambridge.
Major Contributions: First Prime Minister of independent India. Played a key role in shaping the country's democratic framework.
Role in Freedom Movement: Close associate of Gandhi, instrumental in the Indian National Congress (INC), led the Salt Satyagraha and Quit India Movement.
Legacy: Architect of modern India’s democracy and economy.
Key Events: First Prime Minister of India (1947-1964), founding member of the Non-Aligned Movement.
Quotes: 'The only alternative to coexistence is codestruction.'
Honors and Awards: India's first Prime Minister, Nehru Planetarium, numerous institutions named after him.

Name: Subhas Chandra Bose
Early Life: Born on January 23, 1897, in Cuttack, Odisha. He was a brilliant student and excelled at Cambridge University.
Major Contributions: Founded the Indian National Army (INA) to fight against British colonial rule. Advocated for armed struggle.
Role in Freedom Movement: President of the Indian National Congress and a key figure in WWII-era resistance.
Legacy: His slogan 'Give me blood, and I will give you freedom' remains iconic. Bose’s mystery disappearance is still debated.
Key Events: Formation of the Indian National Army, Azad Hind Radio broadcasts.
Quotes: 'Give me blood, and I will give you freedom.'
Honors and Awards: Posthumously honored, statues across India, his legacy is debated in both India and abroad.

Name: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel
Early Life: Born on October 31, 1875, in Nadiad, Gujarat. He was a lawyer and initially took part in several social reform movements.
Major Contributions: Played a crucial role in the integration of princely states into the Indian Union. First Deputy Prime Minister and Home Minister of India.
Role in Freedom Movement: Led the Satyagraha in Bardoli and was a prominent leader in the Quit India Movement.
Legacy: Known as the 'Iron Man of India' for his leadership in unifying the country.
Key Events: Integration of States (1947-49), Steel Frame of India.
Honors and Awards: Statue of Unity, India's highest civilian honor, numerous institutions named after him.

Name: Bhagat Singh
Early Life: Born on September 28, 1907, in Banga, Punjab (now in Pakistan). His family was deeply involved in the struggle for independence.
Major Contributions: Revolutionary leader advocating for armed resistance against British rule. Instrumental in the killing of John Saunders to avenge Lala Lajpat Rai’s death.
Role in Freedom Movement: Martyr for the cause of Indian independence. His execution on March 23, 1931, galvanized the youth.
Legacy: Symbol of youth rebellion and patriotism in India.
Key Events: Jalianwala Bagh Massacre protests, execution in Lahore Central Jail.
Honors and Awards: Statues in his honor, memorials in India and abroad, schools named after him.

Name: Rani Lakshmi Bai
Early Life: Born on November 19, 1828, in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh. She was married to Maharaja Gangadhar Rao and became the queen of Jhansi.
Major Contributions: Led her army against the British during the 1857 Revolt.
Role in Freedom Movement: Symbolized resistance against British oppression during the First War of Indian Independence (1857).
Legacy: A symbol of courage and resilience in India’s struggle for independence.
Key Events: Battle of Jhansi (1857), died in combat.
Quotes: 'Main apne desh ke liye jaan de dungi.' (I will give my life for my country).
Honors and Awards: Statues, schools, and roads named after her across India.

Name: Bal Gangadhar Tilak
Early Life: Born on July 23, 1856, in Ratnagiri, Maharashtra. He was a scholar, lawyer, and social reformer.
Major Contributions: A prominent freedom fighter and social reformer. Known for his slogan 'Swaraj is my birthright.'
Role in Freedom Movement: Advocated for the idea of 'self-rule' and led the Home Rule Movement.
Legacy: Influenced generations of leaders, including Gandhi, and was one of the first to demand full independence.
Key Events: Home Rule Movement (1916), arrested in 1908 for sedition.
Quotes: 'Swaraj is my birthright, and I shall have it.'
Honors and Awards: Several institutions and universities named after him.

Name: Lala Lajpat Rai
Early Life: Born on January 28, 1865, in Dhudike, Punjab. A lawyer and social reformer.
Major Contributions: Leader of the reformist movement in Punjab. Led protests against the Simon Commission in 1928.
Role in Freedom Movement: Famously injured during the baton charge by the police. His death was a catalyst for the rise of revolutionary activities in India.
Legacy: A symbol of bravery in the face of colonial repression.
Key Events: Protests against the Simon Commission, death in 1928.
Quotes: 'The sword of revolution is sharpened on the whetting stone of ideas.'
Honors and Awards: Honored posthumously with memorials and statues in India.

Name: Chandra Sekhar Azad
Early Life: Born on July 23, 1906, in Bhavra, Madhya Pradesh. He was involved in revolutionary activities from a young age.
Major Contributions: A revolutionary leader and a key figure in the Hindustan Socialist Republican Association (HSRA).
Role in Freedom Movement: Known for his role in several major attacks against the British, including the Kakori Train Robbery.
Legacy: A symbol of youthful rebellion, he vowed never to be captured alive by the British, committing suicide when surrounded.
Quotes: 'Dushman ki goliyon ka hum samna karenge, Azad hi rahe hain, Azad hi rahenge.' (We will face the bullets of the enemy, we will remain free forever).
Honors and Awards: Statues in his honor, schools named after him.

Name: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar
Early Life: Born on April 14, 1891, in Mhow, Madhya Pradesh. Came from a low-caste family and faced discrimination.
Major Contributions: Architect of the Indian Constitution and leader of the Dalit community.
Role in Freedom Movement: Fought against untouchability and worked for the rights of the lower castes.
Legacy: Regarded as one of the foremost intellectuals and social reformers in India.
Key Events: Drafted the Indian Constitution, founded the Dalit Buddhist movement.
Honors and Awards: Bharat Ratna (posthumously), Ambedkar Memorials, Dr. Ambedkar Institute of Technology.

Name: Rajguru
Early Life: Born on August 24, 1908, in Khed, Maharashtra. He was a nationalist and revolutionary leader.
Major Contributions: Revolutionary associated with Bhagat Singh and Sukhdev.
Role in Freedom Movement: Participated in the assassination of J.P. Saunders.
Legacy: Martyr for the cause of India's independence.
Key Events: Execution with Bhagat Singh and Sukhdev in 1931.

Name: Sukhdev Thapar
Early Life: Born on May 15, 1907, in Ludhiana, Punjab. A dedicated revolutionary.
Major Contributions: Revolutionary leader associated with Bhagat Singh and Rajguru.
Role in Freedom Movement: Co-accused in the killing of John Saunders.
Legacy: Like Bhagat Singh, he was executed at a young age, leaving behind a legacy of bravery.
Key Events: Execution with Bhagat Singh and Rajguru in 1931.

Name: Mangal Pandey
Early Life: Born on July 19, 1827, in Nagwa, Uttar Pradesh. A sepoy in the British East India Company.
Major Contributions: A sepoy in the British East India Company, Pandey played a crucial role in the 1857 revolt.
Role in Freedom Movement: His attack on British officers sparked the uprising.
Legacy: Considered one of the first martyrs of India’s freedom struggle.
Key Events: The first shot of the revolt in Barrackpore, his execution in 1857.

Name: Kasturba Gandhi
Early Life: Born on April 11, 1869, in Porbandar, Gujarat. Wife of Mahatma Gandhi, she was an activist.
Major Contributions: Participated in several movements alongside Gandhi, particularly in the Salt March.
Role in Freedom Movement: Her support for Gandhi's movement was integral to his success.
Legacy: Symbol of resilience and dedication to the Indian independence movement.
Honors and Awards: Statues and memorials in her honor.

Name: Sarojini Naidu
Early Life: Born on February 13, 1879, in Hyderabad, India. A renowned poet and social activist.
Major Contributions: Known as the 'Nightingale of India' for her poetic contributions.
Role in Freedom Movement: First woman to become the president of the Indian National Congress.
Legacy: One of the foremost women leaders in India’s struggle for independence.
Key Events: Presidency of INC in 1925, Poetic contributions.
Quotes: 'A country's greatness lies in its undying ideals of love and sacrifice.'
Honors and Awards: India's first woman governor, memorials in her honor.

Name: Aurobindo Ghosh
Early Life: Born on August 15, 1872, in Kolkata, West Bengal. A philosopher and nationalist.
Major Contributions: Led the Anushilan Samiti, a revolutionary group in Bengal.
Role in Freedom Movement: Promoted the idea of complete independence through revolutionary means.
Legacy: Later became a spiritual leader and founded the concept of Integral Yoga.
Key Events: Formation of the Anushilan Samiti, his spiritual retreat in Pondicherry.
Quotes: 'The future belongs to those who believe in the beauty of their dreams.'
Honors and Awards: Statues and schools named after him.
